trial_identification.studytitle: Nutritional late effects of childhood cancer
trial_identification.scientifictitle: The body composition, bone health, dietary intake, physical activity and quality of life of children, adolescents and young adults who have undergone treatment for childhood cancer.

interventions.interventions: Observation of body composition and bone health using total body potassium, air displacement plethysmography, DXA, BIA and anthropometry. Collection of diet intake, physical activity and quality of life through diaries and questionnaires. There will be a single visit where measurements will be taken. Testing time will be approximately 1.5 hours. The single visit will occur any time after 2 years post treatment.
interventions.comparator: Compared to age and gender matched controls

primaryOutcome.outcome: Body composition will be assessed using air displacement plethysmography, bioelectrical impedance analysis, dual energy, x-ray absorptiometry and total body potassium counting.
primaryOutcome.timepoint: One measurement at one visit - at least two year post treatment

primaryOutcome.outcome: Bone Density by dual energy x-ray absorptiometry
primaryOutcome.timepoint: One measurement at one visit - at least 2 years post treatment

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Dietary Intake by 3 day diet diary
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: One measurement at one visit - At least 2 years post treatment

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Physical Activity by 3 day physical activity diary
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: One measurement at one visitAt least 2 years post treatment
One measurement at one visit- At least 2 years post treatment

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: 1) Treated at Royal Children's Hospital Brisbane for cancer 2) At least 2 years post active treatment

sponsorship.primarysponsoraddress: Children's Nutrition Research Center Level 4, RCHF Building Herston Rd Royal Children's Hospital Herston, QLD 4029

fundingsource.fundingaddress: Herston Rd, Royal Children's Hospital Brisbane QLD 4029

secondarysponsor.sponsoraddress: Children's Nutrition Research Center Level 4, RCHF Building Herston Rd Royal Children's Hospital Herston, QLD 4029

ethicsAndSummary.summary: This study will look at the body composition, bone health, quality of life, physical activity and dietary intake of childhood cancer survivors (CCS) and determine whether the use of a nutritional screening tool is indicative of nutritional status and body composition. Who is it for? You may be eligible to join this study if you are aged between 5 and 25 years, were treated at the Royal Childrens Hospital for cancer and are at least 2 years post active treatment. Study details All participants will undergo body composition and bone health examinations using techniques such as total body potassium counting, air displacement plethysmography, and dual x-ray absorptiometry. Participants will also complete questionnaires on quality of life, physical activity and dietary intake. Only one visit of approximately 1.5 hours will be required to undertake the measurement. The proposed research project will ultimately allow childhood cancer survivors to have the best chance of nutritional health, growth, quality of life and optimal health in the long term. This work has immediate clinical relevance, with expected outcomes to guide clinical practice.
